patterns.name: false_confidence
patterns.description: Stating unverified technical claims about third-party services as established fact, when the approach depends entirely on them being correct.
patterns.notes: Instance 1: Asserted Protonmail's forwarding delimiter format without verification. Corrected by user â€” actual delimiter is '------- Forwarded Message -------'. Instance 2: Asserted CloudMailin's JSON payload contains a 'plain' field without verification. The entire notes-extraction approach depends on this field existing. Not yet verified. Both instances share the same structural error: assuming third-party service behavior that should be checked against docs or real data.

patterns.name: shallow_exploration
patterns.description: Presenting alternatives only to dismiss them rather than genuinely developing multiple approaches with tradeoff analysis. Alternatives serve as rhetorical contrast for a pre-committed recommendation.
patterns.notes: First instance: Plan presented 'Why not parse from HTML?' and 'Why not use subject line?' as dismissals (~60 words each) rather than developed alternatives. The recommended approach got ~250 words. No tradeoff matrix or 'what each approach optimizes for' analysis. CLAUDE.md mandates: 'Never commit to the first viable approach. Always explore at least two, preferably three. Present tradeoffs.' Conclusion was likely correct but process was non-compliant.
